title-group.article-title: Phelps, Hysteresis, and the Natural Rate of Unemployment

abstract.p: Phelps invented the theory of the natural rate of unemployment at about the same time as Friedman. When elaborating this theory, however, Phelps produced a hysteresis augmented version of the natural rate which has unnatural implications. Higher unemployment, for example, is postulated to leave a legacy of a less skilled labor force in which fewer people have habits conducive to work. The pattern of job vacancies and wages is not likely to change overnight, so a higher natural rate of unemployment will ensue. This paper employs a simple model to illustrate the workings of hysteresis effects and discusses the implications of holding such a view for the interpretation of macroeconomic phenomena.
